Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(2) Abstract

A mobile device is a computer you carry around with you. Today, any mobile device has some capability to access the Web, and a quickly growing percentage of all Web usage is done on mobile devices. Clearly, web content needs to be adadpted for the wide variety of sizes, shapes, and functionality of mobile devices. More importantly, however, mobile devices open new possibilities for adapting content based on a user's context.



Rise of the Mobile WebRise of the Mobile Web

Rise of the Mobile Web Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(4) Rise of the Mobile Web

  • There are far more mobile devices than personal computers in the world
    • Approximate 1 billion PCs vs. 4 billion mobile
  • Increasingly, mobile devices have Web capability
  • A small but quickly growing segment of all Web access is done from mobile devices
  • Improved Web access is viewed as a major factor in the recent success of "smartphones"


Rise of the Mobile Web Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(5) Rise of the Mobile Platform

  • Nearly half (47%) of all Americans report getting some news and info from mobile phone
  • 42% get weather updates 37% get local restaurant and business info.
  • 13% report using an "app" to get this local and practical info
  • While almost half of all adults get info on mobile, just 1 in 10 use an app for this (app-gap)
    Source: Pew Internet and American Life Project, "2011 State of the News Media Report" [http://www.pewinternet.org/Reports/2011/Local-mobile-news.aspx]


Rise of the Mobile Web Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

Mobile Browsers Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(10) Early Mobile Browsers

  • Early mobile browsers weren't really Web browsers at all
  • Mobile devices didn't have much computing power
    • Rendering full web pages wasn't possible
    • Special markup languages instead of HTML
  • Mobile networks were slow
    • Mobile providers proprietary protocols optimized for mobile networks
  • Content providers had to develop separate mobile sites and invest in special "gateway" servers CNN.com adapted for mobile [http://www.google.com/gwt/n?q=cnn.com&site=search&hl=en&lr=&c2coff=1&safe=off&mrestrict=xhtml&ct=res&cd=1&rd=1&u=www.cnn.com/]

Mobile Browsers Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(13) Mobile Web Browsers

  • As mobile devices got more powerful, proprietary markup languages were abandoned for HTML
  • As mobile networks got faster, proprietary protocols were abandoned for HTTP
  • Easier for content providers to adapt their content
  • Improved interaction design reduced need for adaption
  • Now we truly have a mobile Web
    • Still worthwhile to design mobile versions of sites


Mobile Browsers Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

Mobile Apps Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(18) Mobile Apps

  • Using a modern mobile web browser, users can browser ordinary web pages
  • However, it may be desirable to adapt content for a mobile device
  • For example, scrolling and zooming can be annoying on a mobile device
  • Sites that expect a lot of mobile use may design a mobile application for accessing their content
  • Two possibilities:
    • A web application built using HTML + CSS + Javascript
    • A native application built using a platform-specific toolkit


Mobile Apps Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(19) Mobile Web Apps

  • A mobile web application [Anatomy of an Advanced Web Application] is built using standard web technologies
    • HTML, CSS, Javascript
  • Screen layout and interaction optimized for mobile
  • Example: Gmail [http://gmail.com]
  • Advantages:
    • Will work on any modern mobile browser
    • Easily updated
  • Disadvantages:
    • Can't access native functionality
    • Limited offline use
    • Hard to charge for web applications


Mobile Apps Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(20) Native Mobile Apps

  • A native application is built using a platform-specific software develop kit, e.g.:
    • iPhone SDK [http://developer.apple.com/iphone/]
    • Android SDK [http://developer.android.com/]
  • Interface is not built using Web technologies
  • But still accessing the Web via HTTP:
    • Web Service APIs [Anatomy of an Advanced Web Application; Web Service APIs (1)]
    • Syndication Formats [Content Syndication (Atom & RSS); Syndication Formats (1)]
  • Advantages:
    • Can use the full functionality of the phone
      • Camera, GPS, compass, accelerometer, etc.
    • Easier offline use
    • Make money!
  • Disadvantages:
    • Harder to develop
    • Have to target a specific platform
    • Users have to install updates


Sensing Context

Sensing Context Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(22) Location

  • Mobile devices can sense location
    • Coordinates using GPS, wifi router, IP address …
    • Orientation using compass
  • Adapting content based on location becomes far more interesting on a mobile device
  • HTML5 includes geolocation, so you do not need a native app to sense corrdinates
  • geo.js HTML 5.0 example [http://diveintohtml5.org/geolocation.html#]
    Source:diveintohtml5.org [http://diveintohtml5.org]
    • but doesn't include orientation info


Sensing Context Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web

(23) Presence

  • Sometimes the presence of objects or people is more important than absolute location
  • QR codes [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QR_Code] can be incorporated into stickers, posters, etc.
  • Newer phones can read ordinary bar codes too
  • Cutting-edge phones can use image recognition [http://www.google.com/mobile/goggles/]
  • People can be sensed via their mobile devices


Sensing Context Erik WildeUC Berkeley School of Information and UC Berkeley School of InformationDilan MahendranUC Berkeley School of Information: Mobile Web
